text:
Hey everyone, not sure if this is the right channel for this but I'm looking for PM/Operations advice on content production

We're trying to scale up content brief production as we have started onboarding a lot of new writers.  We would be looking at 1,000+ content briefs this year alone.  We're currently using SEO Surfer for content optimization and we have our own internal process on building content briefs using SEMRush and SEO Surfer.  It's fairly thorough and covers possible cannibalization, search intent, competition analysis, KW research, amongst other things.  Usually it takes me 30 minutes to complete each one but the real problematic ones can sometimes take an upwards of an hour.  I dont have a benchmark for what the standard time to build a content brief should be, so that adds more uncertainty to the issue.

I'm not sure if the bottleneck should be solved by hiring several contractors to build out more briefs or by simplifying what might be an overcomplicated content brief process.  Any insight?  We have never been a mass content producer but we are starting to head in that direction and any insight would be great.

text:
I see a lot of teams spending 60-90 minutes on briefs, so 30 isn't bad if you're giving them a full outline. With or without the outline, you can likely get your process down to 10-20 minutes, and IMO it is worth getting process improved before hiring out more folks to build briefs.

It's also possible to train up your writers better and make them self-briefing, but, you're going to end up increasing writing costs in the process, so it's a question of what type of writers you're hiring and whether it's better to have them 'full stack' or focused on the writing itself.

I'd be happy to walk you through Content Harmony if you're interested. This is the exact workflow we were built to solve, and we have <https://www.contentharmony.com/superpath/|a Superpath partner offer> as well.

text: FWIW, my business produces content briefs for SEO with that kind of volume.  You should definitely be able to SOP and parallelize it enough to sic a bunch of contractors or VAs on parts of it to do it in bulk.  Things like looking up basic stats, assessing cannibalization risk, and competitiveness are easy to train, and you can reserve a more expert eye to review people's takes on things like search intent and qualifying keywords

text: I’m just here in solidarity as someone who has to produce a ton of briefs each week. Usually takes me 30 mins for short-form/blog content, and can be 2-3 hours for long form content (longer for new topics).
